did.abstract: Writer and diplomat who served in the Philippines, 1900-1901 and 1905, and Mexico, 1903-1907; papers include correspondence, travel journals, photographs, and scrapbooks.

acqinfo.p: The collection came from different sources. In 1943, the estate of Edwin C. Goddard donated the travel accounts of LeRoy's trips to the Philippines. Donor no. 1872 LeRoy's daughter, Mrs. Elizabeth Kallock donated additional miscellaneous materials in the 1970s and 1983. Donor no. 5281

bioghist.p: James A. LeRoy was born December 9, 1875 in Pontiac, Michigan. He was educated at the University of Michigan, graduating in 1896. He returned to Pontiac as a public school principal but soon thereafter accepted a position with the Detroit Free Press as a sports writer. He moved on to the Detroit News as a political writer, then to the Baltimore Herald. In 1901, while working in Baltimore, LeRoy came to the attention of Dean C. Worcester, who selected him to serve as private secretary to the Philippine Commission. He easily mastered Spanish and became a student of Spanish and Philippine history. While in the Philippines, LeRoy's work gained the approval of Governor General William Howard Taft who entrusted him with other, increasing responsibilities. Skilled as a writer, LeRoy was uniquely qualified to communicate his impressions of the Philippines in the few years after the 1898 war. In the coming years, he would write extensively, notably his monograph, Philippine life in town and country. Unfortunately poor health forced LeRoy to resign before completing his two-year assignment. He returned to Pontiac and then accepted appointment as consul to Durango, Mexico from August 1903 to March 1907. His service in Mexico was briefly interrupted when selected to accompany now Secretary of War Taft as part of a congressional delegation to the Philippines in 1905. LeRoy died in Fort Bayard, New Mexico on February 26, 1909.

scopecontent.p: The collection documents the academic career of LeRoy as a student at the University of Michigan and his two trips to the Philippines in 1901 and 1905. The materials have been groups into four series: Biographical/Personal, Philippine Islands, Durango, Mexico, and Scrapbooks.

The Biographical/Personal series consists of a biographical sketch of LeRoy written by his daughter, correspondence written to his wife while serving in Durango, Mexico, and miscellaneous personal letters.

The Philippine Islands series is notable for LeRoy's extended journal account of his activities and observations while traveling in the Philippines in 1900-1901 and 1905. LeRoy was a keen and perceptive observer and his skill as a writer manifests itself in these journal/travelogues.

scopecontent.p: The Scrapbook series consists of five volumes containing clippings and memorabilia detailing his student life at the University of Michigan in the mid-1890s and his service in the Philippines and Mexico. Included are clipping copies of some of the articles that he wrote for various newspapers.
